newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil overseas credit card curbs may help BOP.
newsitem.headline: Brazil overseas credit card curbs may help BOP.

text.p: A ban on the financing of overseas credit card purchases may have a significant impact on Brazil's current account gap, according to figures published Monday by the Central Bank.
In a statement, the Central Bank said credit card purchases abroad in the January to April period this year were $1.152 billion.
In the whole of 1996, international credit card purchases amounted to $2.955 billion with $813 million in the January-April period, the bank said.

The National Monetary Council (CMN) last Thursday restricted credit card purchases abroad by prohibiting them to be financed. Goods and services bought with plastic abroad will have to be paid off 100 percent when credit card bills come due.
The measure was seen as another move to narrow the current account gap, which reached 3.9 percent of gross domestic product in the 12 months to April compared with 3.25 percent for 1996.
The services account deficit in the first four months of the year came to $7.550 billion, of which $1.237 billion was due to international travel, including overseas credit card purchases.
